Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "How to locally access an Azure Search service?" (#7170) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody: When I run the code locally, the search code is accessing Lucene and returning zero results. Is there a way to access NuGet's search service? Or a custom Azure Search service?

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Gallery search UI should have "search is down" message instead of empty results" (#7169) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Right now (latest search doe in `dev`) if both USNC search and USSC search are down, gallery will show empty results on the `/packages` page.

Basically anywhere `SearchResults` is used without observing `IsSuccessful`, this is possible.

We should have a pretty banner saying "Sorry, search is down right now. Please check the status page." or something like this instead of deceiving the user with 0 results found.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Align the V2 source URL and V2 push URL so alleviate confusion" (#7168) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
## Trying to restore from the push endpoint

Over 10,000 requests in the past 90 days were for `GET` on the V2 push URL (which expects `PUT`):
```
https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package
```

```
requests
| where timestamp > ago(90d) 
| where url endswith "/api/v2/package" or url endswith "/api/v2/package/" or url contains "/api/v2/package/Packages(" or url contains "/api/v2/package/$metadata" or url contains "/api/v2/package/Search()" or url contains "/api/v2/package/FindPackagesById()"
| where name !contains "Errors/"
| where name startswith "GET" 
| summarize sum(itemCount) by bin(timestamp, 1d)
| render timechart 
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/57948668-1ccb6f80-7897-11e9-84bf-6eafe30a11d1.png)

## Trying to push to the restore endpoint

Over 4000 requests in the past 90 days were for `PUT` on the V2 feed URL (which expects `GET`):

```
https://www.nuget.org/api/v2
```

```
requests
| where timestamp > ago(90d) 
| where url endswith "/api/v2" or url endswith "/api/v2/"
| where name !contains "Errors/"
| where name startswith "PUT" 
| summarize sum(itemCount) by bin(timestamp, 1d)
| render timechart 
```

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/57947591-299a9400-7894-11e9-8ae8-ba4d1596f056.png)

## Conclusion

This indicates to me that people are confused between the two URLs. It is relatively simple to fall into this case because our docs used to suggest the push URL being "https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package" and at a cursory glance this may look like the V2 feed URL. Also, if you want to `nuget.exe push -source <name>` you need to add the push URL as a source, which works for push but breaks in VS:

We could simplify this by redirecting allow `PUT` at `https://www.nuget.org/api/v2`. This is very simple because it's one URL.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/94054/57956249-3a0b3880-78ad-11e9-94ef-8a1c21778c04.png)

```
[V2Push] The V2 feed at 'https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package/Search()?$filter=IsAbsoluteLatestVersion&searchTerm=''&targetFramework='net472'&includePrerelease=true&$skip=0&$top=26&semVerLevel=2.0.0' returned an unexpected status code '400 The format of the package id is invalid'.
``

We could also redirect `GET https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package/*` to `GET https://www.nuget.org/api/v2/package/*` but this is complicated with the .nupkg download URL so maybe less achievable.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "Remove the old search." (#7145) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
There are two changes in this PR:
1. Remove the code related with the previous search functionality.
2. Make the Search http client timeout configurable in web.config.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Align unit test package dependencies in NuGet.Services.Metadata" (#7167) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Multiple versions of `moq`, `xunit`, and `xunit.runner.visualstudio` are installed.
This causes multiple build warnings and potentially test runner issues.
These package dependencies can be consolidated to avoid polluting PRs and other branches with these changes.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[Database Migration] Fix CI and Enhance protection. " (#7150) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Need to generate the artifacts for different target databases in the build script.
Wait for the logger to send telemetry.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "[Azure Search] Implement randomized A/B test for new search service" (#7166) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Very simple approach.

1. Randomly return a cookie to the user: `previewSearch = true | false`
    - Get the randomness percentage from JSON content file
1. With this cookie as `true`, use the preview search instead
    - Need a cookie so pagination isn't totally crazy and a single user has a consistent experience
1. Add feature flag to turn this off if things go bad.

This should happen once we have decently acceptable results.

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Packages in dotnet\sdk\NuGetFallbackFolder have invalid signature" (#8143) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
A relapse of #7414 has occurred:

> Warning	NU3005	Package 'System.Memory 4.5.1' from source 'C:\Program Files\dotnet\sdk\NuGetFallbackFolder': The package signature file entry is invalid. The central directory header field 'compression method' has an invalid value (8).	

Repro steps:

```
git clone https://github.com/aarnott/nerdbank.streams.git
cd nerdbank.streams\src
nerdbank.streams.sln
```

Restore and build in VS.

VS version: 28916.44.d16.2

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "Don't warn about native DLLs outside lib" (#8142) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Details about Problem

The warning NU5100 purports to warn about Assemblies outside of the `lib` folder. However, it also warns about Native Dlls outside of the lib folder ([and, indeed, anything with the extension dll](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/3803820961f4d61c06d07b179dab1d0439ec0d91/src/NuGet.Core/NuGet.Packaging/Rules/MisplaceAssemblyOutsideLibRule.cs#L32)).

This can be ignored with nuget.exe's `-NoPackageAnalysis` flag, but that is a bit overkill when I only want to avoid specific instances of a specific warning. If there were a way to disable this specific warning entirely (as the comments in https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/5655 seem to suggest is possible, although I don't see anything in `nuget help pack` about how to ignore specific codes), I'd still rather not disable it completely.

I'd like:

**A.** NuGet to inspect the dlls it's complaining about to see if they are indeed managed assemblies

or

**B.**  a way to disable warnings for specific files (in this case the Native dlls)

As a workaround, native dlls can be put in `\lib\native`, although in my case that isn't exactly where I want them.

NuGet.exe (version 5.0.2.5988) 
Windows 10 v1809 (17763.379)
I'm also using  Visual Studio 17, Version 15.8.8

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

See attached project, below

`HelloNativeDll.dll` is a native dll, and `HelloManagedLibrary.dll` is a Managed Assembly.

The included `nuspec` file puts the native dll where I might want it, but also "misplaces" a .NET assembly, since the point here is that I'd like to reduce spurious warnings without hiding actual problems.

`pack-Expect1WarningGet2.bat` does what it says: runs nuget pack and gets two warnings: one for the native dll put where I wanted it, and one for a managed assembly that is a legitimate warning. Ideally, it would only produce the latter. 

### Sample Project
[NuGetNativeDllExample.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/3194659/NuGetNativeDllExample.zip)

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "error NU1101: Unable to find package - Azure DevOps (Private Nuget)" (#8132) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
## Environment

VS version (if appropriate): 2017 or 2019

OS version : Hosted Ubuntu 1604

Environment: Azure Devops Build Pipeline

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. Create a new ASP.NET Core Web Application
2. Under Nuget Package Manager add a "Package Source" that point to my private source.
3. Install the nuget package from your source.
4. Add docker support to the project. (Rick click project, Add, Docker Support). Edit the Dockerfile.

`FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/aspnet:2.2-stretch-slim AS base
WORKDIR /app

FROM mcr.microsoft.com/dotnet/core/sdk:2.2-stretch AS build
WORKDIR /src
COPY . .
COPY *.csproj ./
COPY nuget.config /
RUN dotnet restore 

COPY . .
WORKDIR "/src"
RUN dotnet build "TestPipeline.csproj" -c Release -o /app

FROM build AS publish
RUN dotnet publish "TestPipeline.csproj" -c Release -o /app

FROM base AS final
WORKDIR /app
COPY --from=publish /app .
ENTRYPOINT ["dotnet", "TestPipeline.dll"]`

5. Upload to Azure git Repo.
6. Create a Build pipeline with the following steps.
     6.1 Nuget Installer
     6.2 Nuget restore (This is successfull and restore packages. I added a Connect Feed for my Nuget package)
     6.3 Commandline task that does `docker build -t testpipeline ./TestPipeline`
7. Queue a build

### Nuget restore details

`==============================================================================
Task         : NuGet
Description  : Restore, pack, or push NuGet packages, or run a NuGet command. Supports NuGet.org and authenticated feeds like Package Management and MyGet. Uses NuGet.exe and works with .NET Framework apps. For .NET Core and .NET Standard apps, use the .NET Core task.
Version      : 2.151.0
Author       : Microsoft Corporation
Help         : [More Information](https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=613747)
==============================================================================`

`NuGet Config files used:
    /home/vsts/work/1/Nuget/tempNuGet_264.config

Feeds used:
    https://company.pkgs.visualstudio.com/_packaging/fcab3aa3-9d0a-4896-b61d-919cff8348e3/nuget/v3/index.json

Installed:
    60 package(s) to /home/vsts/work/1/s/TestPipeline/TestPipeline.csproj
##[section]Finishing: NuGet restore`

### Error log

`Step 9/18 : RUN dotnet restore #"TestPipeline/TestPipeline.csproj"
 ---> Running in 0843de55d156
/src/TestPipeline.csproj : error NU1101: Unable to find package Company.Connect.Shared.Logging. No packages exist with this id in source(s): nuget.org
  Restore failed in 1.5 sec for /src/TestPipeline.csproj.
The command '/bin/sh -c dotnet restore #"TestPipeline/TestPipeline.csproj"' returned a non-zero code: 1
##[error]Bash exited with code '1'.
##[section]Finishing: Build Docker Image`

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "Should dependent assemblies less than or equal to projet's target be added when package is installed?" (#7740) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
PM> $host

Name             : Package Manager Host
Version          : 4.9.3.5777
InstanceId       : d190a8ae-335c-4f75-9f14-09ac364bee12
UI               : System.Management.Automation.Internal.Host.InternalHostUserInterface
CurrentCulture   : en-US
CurrentUICulture : en-US


NuGet Version: 4.9.2.5706
usage: NuGet <command> [args] [options]
Type 'NuGet help <command>' for help on a specific command.




[This document](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/create-packages/supporting-multiple-target-frameworks) says:

> If a match is not found, NuGet copies the assembly for the highest version that is less than or equal to the project's target framework, if available. 

Question: If a match is not found will NuGet also copy *dependent assemblies* for less-than-or-equal versions of project's target framework?


Example Project configuration:
MyApp.exe - net472
depends on
MyDll.dll - net472
depends on
OtherDll.dll - net47 or greater


nuspec:


	<files>
		<file src="bin\$configuration$\*.dll" target="lib\net47" /> 
	</files>
	
	
Build command:
NuGet.exe pack MyDll.csproj -Outputdirectory bin\release -properties Configuration=Release

This is what is created in the .nupkg:

	\lib\net47
		OtherDll.dll
	\lib\net472
		MyDll.dll
	

When I add the .nupkg via Visual Studio to MyApp.exe project only MyDll.dll is added - OtherDll.dll is not added.
My question stated differently is:  Should nuget install BOTH .dll files?  Each one has an assembly that is less than or equal to the project's target framework.

[See also](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7590#event-2096082728)

https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7316

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "nuget list & add commands are being deprecated in 5.0" (#34) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
Tracking Issue(s):
* Deprecate ambiguous nuget.exe commands in 5.0 [#7753](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7753)
  * Deprecate nuget.exe add command [#7923](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7923)
  * Rename nuget.exe list to nuget.exe search [#7912](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7912)

The following commands are being deprecated because these are cause of confusion due to their nomenclature and/or other related commands that already exist:
* [`nuget list`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-list): Currently displays a list of packages from a given source
  * This will be replaced by an equivalent command **`nuget search`** which will be later enhanced with more capabilities as we make progress with or [search improvements](nvmd got it: https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/6371​​​​​​​).
* [`nuget add`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/tools/cli-ref-add): Currently adds a specified package to a non-HTTP package source (a folder or UNC path) in a hierarchical layout, wherein folders are created for the package ID and version number. 
  * This will be replaced by overloading **`nuget push`** command.

> These commands will be deprecated i.e. there will be a warning on usage of these commands in 5.0 so that in future releases these commands can be discontinued.
